The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some controversy. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a categorical foundation for quantum mechanics. The present paper is a contribution to this debate. We provide a categorical foundation for quantum mechanics that is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This is a significant advance over previous attempts.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are of interest because of their extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that the myxozoans are a sister taxon to the cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. We also show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported animal genomes and that the myxozoan body plan was reduced to a minimal set of essential genes. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This is an important step in understanding the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa. (Show more)

The ability of the host immune system to recognize and eliminate pathogens is a key factor in the fight against infectious diseases. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the nuclear import machinery to evade the antiviral action of interferon (IFN). We show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with the Nup98-Rae1 complex to impair nuclear import of ISGs. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms of viral antagonism and suggest that targeting the Nup98-Rae1 complex could be a promising strategy to combat SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. However, the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This will increase the instability of global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the 800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species partition food-plant species is unknown because species-level identification of food plants is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that herbivore diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may be particularly important in light of the current global biodiversity crisis.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the distribution of floating plastic debris is mostly related to the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of plastic debris smaller than 1 mm by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered.

The origin of the elements is one of the most important questions in astrophysics. The study of presolar grains, which are found in meteorites, is one of the most promising ways to understand the formation of the elements. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million more motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries.

The ability to reproduce is the defining characteristic of all life. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output and the mechanisms by which allomaternal care and domestication increase reproductive output. We find that all forms of external energetic supplementation increase reproductive output without compromising offspring size. The greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals and other species that practice allonursing. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other by a network of communication channels. The network is composed of clusters of cells that are connected to each other by short paths. The network is also composed of shortcuts that connect cells that are not part of the clusters. The network is highly efficient in the transmission of information and is able to quickly respond to changes in the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health surveillance and epidemiological modeling. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including many auxiliary indicators that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API is designed to be easy to use and to provide access to all of the data in a common format. We provide examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. The allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health and disease. The role of the anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood, but they are known to produce a variety of bioactive compounds. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We identify a large number of genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for natural products, and we demonstrate that these fungi produce a variety of bioactive compounds. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is mediated by the nucleus accumbens and that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, which enhances brain energy metabolism, prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the limited knowledge of material properties and the complex and time-consuming process of trial and error. Here, we propose a digital synthesis approach to design mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. The structures are digitally synthesized by a free-form inverse design method, which is based on the principle of least action and the principle of virtual work. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, which is based on the principle of selective removal of material. The structures are assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex and navigable responses. The proposed approach can be utilized to design mechanical devices with desired behaviors for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is highly dynamic and is regulated by a complex network of factors. Here we investigated the role of insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroblasts. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in human erythroblasts and that its expression is developmentally regulated. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can mediate the reprogramming of hemoglobin expression in human erythroblasts, resulting in a more fetal-like pattern of hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. It is regulated by cellular metabolism, redox homeostasis, and various signaling pathways related to cancer. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or SCD1 sensitized ferroptosis in cancer cells

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the use of antihypertensive drugs is the main strategy to prevent heart failure. However, the use of antihypertensive drugs is associated with the development of heart failure. The major class of antihypertensive drugs is the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are used to treat hypertension. Our study shows that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our study provides a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrates that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated birds and stabilizing early-seral–associated birds. We found that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral–associated birds, but failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated birds. Our results suggest that the NWFP has not been effective in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, and that the policy needs to be revised to ensure that older forests are conserved and developed.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, their membrane permeability, and their binding affinity to the ribosome. The best candidate was tested in vitro and in vivo, and it was found to be active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The approach is general and can be applied to other antibiotic classes. The approach is also applicable to the design of new drugs for other diseases.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results suggest that the proposed architecture is a promising candidate for future work in this area.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is one of the most diverse and best-known groups of endemic species on Earth. The species flock is found in a single lake, which has undergone dramatic changes in hydroclimate over the past 1.3 My. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind record of the hydroclimate of the region, which shows that the lake underwent a major shift in hydroclimate at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), which is also associated with the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock. The shift in hydroclimate is associated with a change in the orbital forcing of the climate system, which is consistent with the observed changes in the cichlid fish species flock. The cichlid fish species flock is a unique example of how the environment can influence the evolution of a species. The rapid evolution of the cichlid fish species flock in response to the changing environment may have enabled the species to adapt to the changing environment and survive the MPT.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly, but the biological effects of this practice on sleep are unknown. Here we compare the biological effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. We found that participants reading an LE-eBook took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. (Show more)

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is a 100-y-long period of abrupt climate change that occurred around 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. The bolide impact hypothesis is supported by the presence of magnetic grains and microspherules in the YDB sediments. However, the origin of the magnetic grains and microspherules is controversial. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules in the YDB sediments are terrestrial in origin. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is unknown. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This is associated with a shift in the balance between Treg and Th17 cells, and the development of a unique autoantibody profile.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles and to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses is a fundamental principle of the immune system. However, the ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses has been limited by the emergence of variants that have evolved to evade the immune system. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance the ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize variants of concern. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by enhancing the neutralizing activity of an antibody that is effective against the Alpha, Beta, and Gamma variants but not the Delta variant. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules and may be used to develop new antibody drug candidates for the current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE.

The apoE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is involved in normal synaptic pruning and turnover. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. We also found that APOE isoform is highly dependent on the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses and enhances synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 1,200 km, which is the deepest part of the Earth. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. One of the most important questions is how the inner core formed. The nucleation mechanism of the inner core is also a key factor in understanding the formation process. In this study, we found that the bcc phase of iron has a higher nucleation rate than the hcp phase of iron under the conditions of the inner core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is likely to be composed of bcc iron. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well established, the underlying mechanisms are not. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to have negative emotionality and addiction. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

The brain’s processing of language is the most studied cognitive process in neuroscience. However, the brain’s mechanisms remain poorly understood, in part because of the complexity of the task and the difficulty of measuring and analyzing the brain’s activity. Here, we use a large-scale, integrative modeling approach to overcome these challenges. We find that the most powerful deep learning models for language processing are also the most predictive of the brain’s activity during language comprehension. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s mechanisms for language comprehension. They also suggest that deep learning models may be a powerful tool for understanding the brain’s mechanisms for language. This approach may be broadly applicable to other complex cognitive processes.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in computer science, but it has not been widely used in scientific computing. This is because of the instability of DL algorithms, which can lead to poor performance or even failure. We show that this instability is due to the fact that DL algorithms are not well-conditioned, meaning that they are not well-suited to the problems that they are being applied to. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are well-conditioned and are able to compute stable neural networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the failure of the medical system to cope with the pandemic, and the failure of people to follow the rules. One of the most prominent arguments is that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is a key factor in the failure of governments to act in time. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years prior to the first case of COVID-19. We discuss the flaws of the experiment and show that it is not only a poor example of psychological research but also supports the conclusion of the experiment.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and the causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense research. However, the pathogenicity of M. lepromatosis, a third leprosy species, has been unknown until now. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. The two species are remarkably similar, and we found that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA of the two species than is M. leprae. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy and may lead to the identification of new drug targets. (Show more)

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a fundamental open problem. Here, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our result is based on a combination of integrability, quasiparticle picture, and a careful analysis of the entanglement spectrum. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a set of quasiparticles, which are the natural generalization of the elementary excitations of the system to the quantum many-body context. Our result provides a framework to study the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems, which is applicable to a wide class of models.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, which may be difficult to administer in low-income countries. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is easy to manufacture and can be administered as a single dose. This vaccine is highly attenuated, which may reduce the risk of severe COVID-19 in vaccinated individuals.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is hypothesized that human ectoparasite vectors, such as fleas or lice, caused the rapidly spreading epidemics. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a framework for understanding the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of plague in Europe. It also provides a model for the spread of other infectious diseases by human ectoparasites.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. Here, we present the largest dataset of its kind and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density in amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies suggest that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others suggest that it is an oncogene. The current study shows that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator in cancer cells, and that its expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is thought to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is unknown. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to filaments and induces severing when the filaments are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist. A simple model, which faithfully recapitulates our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF-induced twist enhances severing 100-fold. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanism for how ADF’s action is enhanced in a mechanical context, which is critical for cells to maintain their shape and function.

The consumption of fructose, a common sugar found in many fruits and in many beverages, has been associated with weight gain. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of fructose and glucose have not been well studied. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. Our results may help explain the increased prevalence of obesity in the United States and may provide insight into the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on health. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The recent demographic history is also reflected in the genomic data, with a geographic influence on the distribution of African and Asian ancestry. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and the settlement of the island. They also provide a reference for the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population, which is a unique population in the world. This information will be useful for the conservation of the Malagasy biodiversity. Finally, the grid-based approach used in this study can be applied to other populations to better understand their history.

The presence of mRNA modifications has been shown to impact the rate of protein synthesis. However, the impact of the most common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), on translation has not been studied. Here, we show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can impede the recruitment of the elongation factor, EF-Tu, and can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This work provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on translation and may have implications for the design of synthetic mRNA therapeutics. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better social and economic well-being, better health, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or of outcome levels before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study examines the drivers of the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals, which have evolved in the water four times independently. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is the most common cause of illness worldwide, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the cause of up to 90% of all colds. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus growth has been attributed to a more efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we show that the temperature dependence of rhinovirus growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria use a variety of sensory systems to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensory system is required for attachment to surfaces, which in turn promotes the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. Our results thus demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This finding has implications for the development of antimicrobial therapies, as the use of pili for sensing surfaces may provide a target for the design of new antibiotics. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to other animal species, including white-tailed deer, which are susceptible to infection. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. We also show that the virus has spread among deer, and that the number of deer-to-deer transmissions is likely to be higher than the number of human-to-deer transmissions. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of hydropower dams, the current state of the industry, and the challenges of building large dams in the developing world. It also proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by chronic inflammation, which is most often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to amyloid-β (Aβ) plaque deposits and cell death. However, this inflammatory reaction is observed in transgenic animal models devoid of such pathologies, suggesting that it may originate from neurons burdened with increasing levels of soluble and oligomeric Aβ, which are known to be the most toxic amyloid species within the brain. Here, we identify a neuron-specific inflammatory response, which may precede insoluble Aβ plaque and tau tangle formation. We propose that this plaque-independent inflammatory reaction originates from neurons burdened with increasing levels of soluble and oligomeric Aβ, which are known to be the most toxic amyloid species within the brain. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the evolution of animal husbandry and the spread of agriculture in the ancient world. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism of bacterial defense. However, the cellular mechanisms that regulate the concentration of Np4 in the cell are not well understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to be the predominant decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, is the primary enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped transcripts in Escherichia coli. We also show that RppH prefers to decapp Np4-capped transcripts over their capped counterparts, and that the enzyme uses a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decapp other transcripts. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress, as well as for the development of new antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease sepsis-induced immunosuppression. We found that citrulline, an amino acid that is converted to arginine in the body, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing sepsis-induced Treg and MDSC expansion. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a potential adjuvant in cancer therapy. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global marine biomass for the functioning of the ecosystem and the need for a better understanding of the biomass of wild marine organisms. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. These results are key for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem and for the conservation of biodiversity.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time toward a critical state in which the system’s activity is maintained at a constant level. SOC systems are characterized by self-similarity and ergodicity breaking. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for quantum applications, but its electronic properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by mechanical strain, and that its bandgap can be tuned continuously from indirect to direct. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. We also show that diamond is stable against phase transition to graphite, which is important for applications of diamond in harsh environments. Our findings are expected to advance the development of diamond-based quantum technologies.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of plants is well established. However, the role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of the plant kingdom is still debated. The evolution of the plant kingdom is also a matter of debate. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and demonstrate its potential as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely to be a site of communication between the sexes. However, the extent to which the female contributes to the male’s reproductive success is largely unknown. Here, we show that the female contributes to the male’s sperm proteome, and that the female contribution is critical for supporting sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular communication between the sexes during the male–female interface. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, through its A1 domain. The A1 domain is conformationally sensitive, and the binding of platelets to VWF is thought to be regulated by conformational changes in the A1 domain. We show that force can switch the conformation of the A1 domain, and that this switch can be used to activate VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism provides a way to regulate the binding of VWF to platelets, and may be important in the regulation of VWF function.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in and on humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. The database is used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results suggest that the human virome is a complex and important component of human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI and the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a matter of intense debate for more than a century. The most widely accepted estimate of the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean, the earliest period of Earth’s history, is 70 ± 15 °C. This estimate is based on the isotopic composition of marine cherts, which is thought to reflect the temperature of the oceans. However, this estimate has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic compositions of the oceans, the possibility of isotopic resetting, and the depositional environment. We here present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the Earth decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are responsible for the regulation of ion flow. The two-pore-domain K+ channel, BK, is a major K+ channel in the heart and is important for cardiac excitability and contractility. The BK channel has two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings may help us understand the BK channel’s normal closing and its role in cardiac arrhythmia. (Show more)

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the host cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a key adhesin, EBA175, to bind to the host cell surface and alter the physical properties of the cell membrane. We show that this interaction leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell membrane. These changes in the membrane properties are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the host cell surface through its binding antigens, altering the physical properties of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion.

Diamond is a promising material for quantum applications, but its electronic properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by mechanical strain, and that its bandgap can be tuned continuously from indirect to direct. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide insights into the stability of diamond under strain and the mechanism of metallization. Our findings are expected to stimulate new research on diamond and related materials.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides insights into the role of humidity in host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome. These findings may help in the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a neural implementation of a merge operation, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be a key to understanding how the brain encodes and processes complex linguistic structures.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in a wide range of biological processes, including development and cancer. The pathway is regulated by two key components, Axin and β-catenin. Axin is a scaffold that binds to β-catenin and inhibits its degradation. We show here that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently in different tissues, which allows for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway. This is an example of a subtle feature that may be important for the regulation of other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the midbrain. This circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it is not involved in the normal control of feeding.

The ability of bacteria to fix nitrogen from the atmosphere is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is essential for the growth of many plants. However, the use of free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is limited by the need to maintain a close association with the plant, which is difficult to achieve in the face of the plant’s immune system. Here, we demonstrate the feasibility of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria are only able to fix nitrogen when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be applied to other nitrogen-fixing symbioses and is expected to have a significant impact on agriculture. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, but it is being lost at an alarming rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program, but the estimated effects are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may be effective in reducing deforestation, but that the effectiveness is limited by the fact that the program’s monitors are perceived to be new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ patrols are perceived to be substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in form and function, but all are made of cells and are part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-spinning spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s hearing is outsourced to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is made of protein and is self-manufactured, self-repairing, and self-regenerated. The spider’s web is 10,000 times larger than its body and can be adjusted to the task at hand. The spider’s web is a unique example of an extended organ that is not constrained by the body and can be used to listen to the world around it.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and aerosols are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions, which are the main source of both pollutants. We find that removing these emissions can reduce the excess mortality rate by 3.61 million per year, which is about 50% of the total excess mortality rate of 7.2 million per year. The model also shows that removing fossil-fuel-generated particles can restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns over large parts of the world, and that reducing tropospheric ozone and methane at the same time can moderate the warming from aerosols. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on global health and the global economy. The development of safe and efficacious vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing and elicits a strong immune response in mice. This variant is also more similar to the RBD of the variants of concern, which may improve the efficacy of antibodies raised against it. This engineered RBD variant may be used to design a VLP vaccine, which may further improve the efficacy of the vaccine.

The role of ALK/Ltk in neural crest development is not fully understood. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk is activated by secreted ALKAL ligands and that the ALKALs are required for zebrafish neural crest development. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/Ltk family receptors by ALKAL ligands and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. These findings may help to understand the role of ALK/Ltk in human cancer and in the development of human neural crest-derived tissues.

The emergence of plague, the deadliest pathogen in human history, is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution and ecology are poorly understood. We present 17 ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, a critical time in the development of the pathogen. Our results show that the LNBA Y. pestis lineage was nonflea-adapted and likely extinct by the Bronze Age, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, and the patterns of dispersal of the disease across Eurasia. This information is critical for understanding the origins of plague and its impact on human history. (Show more)

The endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—is associated with support for Donald Trump in the United States. This study examines the role of HM in men’s and women’s support for Trump in the 2016 and 2020 presidential elections. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also suggest that the endorsement of HM may be a more robust predictor of candidate support than social and prejudiced attitudes. The findings are discussed in terms of the implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical question for the global food system and climate change. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage in the top 15 cm of soil, but the extent to which these practices can mitigate the loss of SOC from agricultural systems is unclear. We demonstrate that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage in the top 15 cm of soil, but the extent to which these practices can mitigate the loss of SOC from agricultural systems is unclear. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of zoonotic spillover and the spread of novel viruses in wildlife. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We used this framework to identify SARS-CoV-2 as a spillover candidate, and to identify other viruses that may pose a future threat. We also developed a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the data and prioritize their own research questions. SpillOver is a living database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards offered by Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) is a blood-red nectar. We show that the red color of this nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a new role for a carbonic anhydrase in the production of nectar pigments and demonstrate that this trait is convergent in two species of hummingbird-visited plants. This work provides evidence for the selective advantage of this type of adaptation and suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the red color of the blood of humans and animals.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. We present genome-wide data from a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, southern Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestry of women is very heterogeneous and includes signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. This is particularly striking in women with artificial skull deformations, who may have originated in southeastern Europe. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. This is important for understanding the genetic history of Europe and the processes that shaped modern Europeans.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of MERS-CoV pathogenesis and the potential risk of zoonotic transmission of bat coronaviruses to

The global pandemic of COVID-19 has highlighted the importance of rapid pathogen surveillance and response. However, the lack of resources in many settings, including resource-scarce Southeast Asia, has made this difficult. We demonstrate that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings, including vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in eukaryotes. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. The human pol δ holoenzyme is known to be extremely stable, but the mechanism by which this stability is achieved is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it is possible to evolve ribozymes that can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template, but it is not known whether such evolved ribozymes can replicate RNA. Here, we report the development of an evolved RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template, replicate RNA, and amplify RNA by more than 10,000-fold. This represents a major step toward the reconstruction of life in the laboratory.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with economic and demographic factors. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements, and that neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is important for urban planning and for the development of computer vision methods for understanding the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of these patients are also studied. The results show that the immune characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are similar to those of patients with other severe and critical diseases, and the pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

The role of copper in fungal biology is well established, but the mechanisms of copper homeostasis are not fully understood. The existence of a fungal natural product that binds copper and impacts cellular copper content is a novel finding. The copper-chelating properties of xan BGC isocyanide products are demonstrated in vitro and in planta, and the role of the xan BGC in copper homeostasis is supported by the presence of this gene cluster in several filamentous fungi. The identification of a fungal natural product that binds copper and impacts cellular copper content has implications for the role of copper in fungal biology and for the interactions of fungi with other microbes. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, is a rare event in nature. The detection of tridymite in a Martian mudstone is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and the amorphous silica, and is possibly derived from a silicic volcanic source. The amorphous silica is cogenetic with the other primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products, and is possibly derived from multiple aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities.

Frost is a major environmental stress that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We analyze the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts and the resistance strategies of woody species to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a recently identified subset of CD4 T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to Th17 cells are not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains a predominantly IL-17A+ phenotype and is unable to induce colitis in recipients, whereas the other, which is dependent on the expression of the transcription factor T-bet, is able to induce colitis and can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is progressive, and death is usually within 3 to 5 y. The disease is fatal, and there is no cure. There is an urgent need to develop disease models and identify effective therapies. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and identify potential therapies. This method will also enable high-throughput drug screening to identify potential therapies. This will greatly accelerate the development of effective therapies for ALS. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the ways in which pathogens influence the composition of the microbiota to enhance colonization are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that alters the composition of the tick microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the vector. We demonstrate that iafgp alters the integrity of the gut barrier and the peritrophic matrix, which are critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. IAFGP also alters the composition of the gut microbiota, which in turn influences the integrity of the gut barrier and the peritrophic matrix. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in vertebrate evolution. The short-tailed bird group is a key group for understanding the origin of the avian body plan, but the diversity of early branching members is limited. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, which adds important information about the origin of the avian body plan. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the climate feedbacks. In this paper, we show that one of the most important feedbacks is the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing tropospheric temperature. This is a positive feedback, and it is important to understand the strength of this feedback because it is one of the largest feedbacks in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. The color of a vertebrate can be modified by the absorption of light in the visual spectrum, but it can also be modified by the emission of light in the infrared spectrum. The latter is a form of communication, but it is also a form of camouflage. In this study, we describe a mechanism of color change in vertebrates that has evolved multiple times during evolution. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This function is important for the survival of the animals, as it provides them with a mechanism to control the color of their bodies.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer cells can be classified into two major populations, the more aggressive tumor-forming cells and the less aggressive tumor-initiating cells. The latter are thought to be responsible for the formation of new tumors. In this study, we show that the expression of a protein, ALKBH5, which is induced by hypoxia, is important for the maintenance of the tumor-initiating phenotype in breast cancer cells. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, but the first pocket Bible was made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. This study uses a noninvasive method to identify the animal origin of the parchment. The results suggest that the source of the parchment was not the use of abortive or newborn animals, but rather a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing of the extinction, the rapid reorganization of the carbon cycle, and the persistence of decamillenial to millennial level fluctuations in the carbon cycle for ∼500 ka suggest that the extinction was triggered by a combination of environmental perturbations and/or a sudden release of carbon from the ocean to the atmosphere.
