The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation in the spike protein is the most prevalent mutation in the currently circulating variants of concern. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent membrane fusion. Our results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein and may inform the development of future variants of concern. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Our findings highlight the need for urgent action to mitigate the structural inequalities that have led to the disproportionate burden of COVID-19 and its consequences. (PsycInfo Database Record

The chemical properties of atoms are fundamental to chemistry and are of great interest to the general public. The chemical hardness and electronegativity of an atom are two central properties that can be calculated for any atom in the periodic table. We show that these properties decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the sign of the effect is uncertain because of feedbacks between fire and climate. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can reduce the warming caused by emissions of greenhouse gases. This is because fires release carbon from the terrestrial ecosystem, but also because they can remove carbon from the atmosphere. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowed by up to 0.11 °C by 2100, but that this effect is sensitive to the rate of emissions.

The provision of nutrients to microbial partners in symbiotic relationships is a well-established mechanism for regulating the growth and health of the host. However, the mechanisms by which the host regulates the activities of the microbial partners in these relationships are less well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is provided to the squid only at night, when the symbiotic organ is at its most active. The glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which in turn modulates the conditions in which they live, enhancing their ability to produce light at night. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis, in which the host provides a nutrient only at a specific time of day, and the host–microbe interaction is thus modulated by the timing of the provision of a single nutrient. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the regulation of the activities of epithelial-associated microbial communities in other hosts.

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important in many domains. However, it is difficult to identify patterns in text data because of the complexity of the data and the sparsity of the patterns. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as sequences of these patterns. We use a generative model to identify the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. It can be applied to many domains and can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics and to model the gendered nature of topics in text data.

The Black Death, the deadliest epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, and it has implications for the study of other emerging infectious diseases. (Show more)

The asteroid mass mortality (AMM) is a recent event that has affected at least 20 species of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animals. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease. The virus is transmitted by the sea star’s natural predators, the tubeworms, and is present in the plankton and in sediments. The virus has been present in the Pacific for at least 72 y, suggesting that it has been present in the ecosystem for a long time.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. We have identified IL1RAP (IL1R3) as a target for therapy of AML. IL1RAP is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can be used to treat primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results suggest that the antibody can be used to treat other diseases in which IL1RAP is expressed.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic history is also reflected in the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island, showing that the settlement was not homogeneous and that the population growth was sex biased. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. It will be a valuable resource for the study of human evolution and migration in the region. (Show more)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases the activity of that enzyme. The protein also interferes with the ability of a second RNA to repress the expression of two other genes. The protein interferes with the ability of the second RNA to repress the expression of the three genes, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate multiple biological processes.

The ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses is a fundamental principle of the immune system. However, the ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize viruses has been limited by the emergence of variants that have evolved to evade the immune system. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance the ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize variants of concern. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by enhancing the neutralizing activity of an antibody that is effective against the Alpha, Beta, and Gamma variants but not the Delta variant. Our approach can be used to identify CDR changes that can improve the ability of antibodies to recognize and neutralize variants of concern. Our approach can potentially be used to develop new antibody drug candidates for the current and emerging variants of SARS-CoV-2. This work can also be extended to other protein molecules.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show that the US Department of Agriculture Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is based on the assessments of thousands of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We show that the CPC is robust and stable over time, and is valid across the nation. We also show that the CPC can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results suggest that the CPC can be used to provide a more accurate and timely assessment of crop conditions and yields, and can be used to improve agricultural decision-making.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. However, there is evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation may also play a role in memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability that occur in neurons when they are repeatedly activated. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet the response of soil respiration to climate change remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of life on Earth. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major evolutionary event in the history of life, and the molecular signature of this transition is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. Our model is based on the assumption that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle is accompanied by the relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. We show that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes of the genome, and that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes of the genome, and that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes of the genome. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks associated with climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for policy makers and the public, as it provides a quantitative assessment of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent drought and its future occurrence. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not well understood. The first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. Like the naturally formed quasicrystals found in the Khatyrka meteorite and experimental shock syntheses of quasicrystals, the anthropogenic quasicrystals in red trinitite demonstrate that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The first step in this reaction, the formation of the isocyclisation intermediate, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron enzyme. We show that the diiron enzyme is a cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS), and is associated with the development and progression of the disease. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is a key regulator of neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, and that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a key role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes may be potential therapeutic targets for reducing neuroinflammation in MS. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. The probability of drought has increased because of a combination of factors. First, the probability of warm conditions has increased. Second, the probability of dry precipitation falling on warm soil has increased. Third, the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased. These factors are expected to continue to increase as the climate warms.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests that the forgetting process is a potential therapeutic target for autism. (Show more)

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also serves to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, but its physiological role has been difficult to determine because of the difficulty in studying its function in vivo. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that, when expressed in cells, result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, leading to spontaneous bleeding and miosis in zebrafish and thrombocytopenia and bleeding in mice. These findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to study the spread of aggregates in the brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and spread throughout the brain, where they are internalized and accumulate in other neurons. We demonstrate that the internalization of aggregates is mediated by endocytosis, and that this process is required for the spread of aggregates. Finally, we show that the internalization of aggregates is important for the spread of disease. These results provide a model for the study of the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for the study of the role of endocytosis in the spread of disease. (Show more)

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases is well established, but the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats to other animals and humans are not fully understood. Here, we identified a protein, Myotis pilosus (MTX), that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent inhibitor of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H), which is responsible for the conversion of leukotriene A4 to leukotriene B4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX inhibited the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitated viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The findings also provide a potential mechanism for the emergence of influenza A virus (IAV) H1N1 infection and pathogenicity in mice. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferse 1/2, which blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited to treat cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, and the presence of these inclusions is a key diagnostic feature of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of inclusions in ALS is a consequence of the disease-related loss of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. This finding may provide a rationale for the use of protein homeostasis-targeting drugs in ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for the study of many-body physics with neutral atoms.

The origin of the Ceratophyllum clade is poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a plant previously described from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees, provides a detailed analysis of this plant, including its anatomy and reproduction. The results suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, and that Montsechia is an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum. This opens the possibility that aquatic habitats were important in the early evolution of the Ceratophyllum clade.

The evolution of viruses is a key component of the history of life on Earth. However, the study of virus evolution is complicated by the fact that most viruses are not cultured in the laboratory, and that the vast majority of viruses are not preserved in the fossil record. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes, which provide insights into the evolution of a human pathogen, parvovirus B19. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype, 2, occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of sea level rise is accelerating. These observations are consistent with the hypothesis that global warming is caused by human activities. The rate of sea level rise is determined by the balance between the rate of thermal expansion of the oceans and the rate of loss of mass from glaciers, ice sheets, and ice caps. The rate of sea level rise is also affected by the rate of climate-change–induced melting of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States, but that the increase has been less for those with less education. However, the increase has been more pronounced for those born after 1950, who are the least educated cohort in the country. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950, and suggests that tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme intermediates is a key goal in the study of catalysis. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this intermediate, including the location of the water molecule that serves as a hydrogen bond donor to the ε-amino group of the catalytic βLys87. The results also provide a mechanistic framework for understanding why indole, an isostere of the natural substrate, is unable to react with the intermediate, while the natural substrate is able to do so. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of enzyme intermediates and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This approach has the potential to provide insight into the mechanism of many enzymes.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV), which has a high case fatality rate. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS-CoV infection. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS-CoV infection. It also provides a rationale for the use of remdesivir in other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This is an important step forward in the fight against this emerging pandemic.

The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is one of the best-studied symbioses in nature. The squid provides a constant supply of nutrients to the symbiont, which in turn provides a source of light to the squid at night. We show here that the squid also provides a specific glycan to the symbiont, which is required for the persistence of the symbiont in the squid’s crypts. The glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting metabolites to maintain a stable symbiosis. This study provides a new example of how a host can regulate the activities of its symbionts through the provision of specific nutrients. This mechanism may be used by other hosts to control the activities of their symbionts. (Show more)

The suspension rate in US schools is 15 times higher than it was in 1972. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through a scalable intervention. In two experiments, teachers who were trained to adopt an empathic mindset about discipline reduced their suspension rates by half. In a randomized field experiment, this intervention also bolstered the respect that suspended students had for their teachers. These findings have implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. (Show more)

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and is a major contributor to the global obesity epidemic. One promising approach to reducing these impacts is to increase the proportion of plant-based meals in catering settings. However, the impact of increasing the proportion of plant-based meals on sales of meat meals has not been studied. We show that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering setting increased sales of vegetarian meals by 40% and decreased sales of meat meals by 15%. These results suggest that increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering settings could be a powerful way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and improve population health.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space, and is a major target for cancer therapy. Here we use quantitative proteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics, and find massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has been shown to be able to evade the host immune system, and it is possible that the accessory protein ORF8 plays a role in this evasion. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. We also show that this protein can form a covalent disulfide-linked dimer, which is unique to SARS-CoV-2. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis for the unique immune evasion and evasion of the host interferon response that has been observed in SARS-CoV-2. This knowledge may lead to the development of new antiviral therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema in humans and animals. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical models. It is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations that we have “cherry picked”—searched for the strongest associations. This paper describes some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrates their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The paper is intended for a general audience of researchers and practitioners in statistics and machine learning.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. Although many attempts have been made to generate ECs from pluripotent stem cells and nonvascular cells, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce vascular ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the development of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs and the development of vascular networks in vitro and in vivo. It also provides a promising approach for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we report the discovery of two ligands for Alk and Ltk, which we named augmentor-α and augmentor-β (also named “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively). We show that these ligands are essential for zebrafish iridophore patterning and that they are essential for Ltk activity in a tissue-specific context. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the function of Alk and Ltk and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Although insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated for T2D, the role of STING in these two molecular bases is unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired insulin secretion in β-cells, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemic. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The atheroprone flow environment is a key factor in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms underlying the atheroprone flow-induced atherogenesis are not fully understood. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the atheroprone flow-induced atherogenesis. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This strategy may be applicable to the treatment of other inflammatory diseases. (Show more)

The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with economic and demographic factors. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements, and that neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is important for understanding the physical dynamics of cities and for developing effective policies to improve the physical appearances of neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a promising approach to pest control, but the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated that dTRPγ ion channel in Drosophila melanogaster mediates avoidance behavior to natural repellents. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the time between cell infection and viral production to be short, the rate of viral production to be rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus to be ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis and the death of the coral host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the stability of the coral holobiont and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the microbiome. In this study, we show that the loss of a tumor suppressor, which leads to the formation of intestinal tumors, leads to a dysbiotic microbiome and barrier dysfunction. We further show that the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response, which in turn stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain intestinal homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer and intestinal diseases. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death in this population. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is often poor. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression was associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. Finally, we found that ROR1 expression was associated with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a matter of debate. The recent discovery of a unique volcanic eruption series at the start of deglaciation provides a unique opportunity to test the hypothesis that the Mount Takahe eruptions caused the deglaciation. We find that the timing of the deglaciation is consistent with the timing of the volcanic eruptions, and that the deglaciation is synchronous with the onset of stratospheric ozone depletion. This finding provides strong support for the hypothesis that the deglaciation was triggered by the Mount Takahe eruptions. The deglaciation was likely triggered by the Mount Takahe eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, and thus to a change in the atmospheric circulation and climate. This finding has implications for the timing of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere and for the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the climate system. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our data can be used to identify regions where fisheries are most productive and biodiversity is most threatened, and to prioritize conservation efforts to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve a high capacity and a low operating potential range. Furthermore, a hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury, a phenomenon that is thought to be due to a lack of activity-dependent mechanisms. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in C. elegans that is independent of the MAPK signaling cascade, a major pathway that is activated during activity-dependent regeneration in mammals. We also find that this form of regeneration is linked to a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for the discovery of genes involved in neuronal regeneration in the mammalian CNS.

Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired to create genetic diversity. It is a fundamental process in biology, and its rate is a key factor in the evolution of genomes. In this study, we use a population of wild monkeyflowers to map the locations of recombination events in a flowering plant. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions that are completely devoid of recombination. These regions are interspersed with regions of intense recombination, which are enriched in genes and in the promoter regions of genes. These results suggest that the distribution of recombination in plants is similar to that in other eukaryotes. This is an important step in understanding the evolution of recombination in plants and in the evolution of the genome.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in activity that are not directly related to the task performed by the subject. These fluctuations are related to the spontaneous activity of the brain, and are thought to be related to the organization of the brain into networks. Here, we used metabolic imaging to identify and validate the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. We found that the dominant resting network was similar to the default mode network, and that this network was subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. The dominant network was also associated with reduced task-related activity in healthy subjects and with cognitive dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease. These results provide a direct link between the organization of the brain in health and disease and the metabolic activity of the brain. They also provide a framework for the development of new imaging techniques that can be used to study the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is a well-known mechanism for regulating translation. The existence of a 5′ cap-like structure on nuclear-encoded mitochondrial and bacterial RNAs has been reported, but the existence of a 5′ cap-like structure on nuclear-encoded nuclear RNAs has not been demonstrated. We report the existence of a 5′ cap-like structure on nuclear-encoded mitochondrial and nuclear RNAs, which is not 5′ end-processed. This 5′ cap-like structure is not required for translation, but may be important for the regulation of mitochondrial gene expression.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) was a landmark study in the field of diabetes, showing that intensive therapy could prevent the development of complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of this therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells from people with diabetes persist for several years after the end of the DCCT, and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of the DCCT.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and has a poor prognosis. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with high morbidity and mortality. The mechanisms underlying the development of alcohol dependence are not fully understood, but it is clear that the brain is involved in the disease. The gut microbiota has been shown to be altered in psychiatric disorders, which suggests the existence of a gut–brain axis. In the present study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of fruit ripening, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is important for the development of flavor. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor, 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. This pathway is unique to tomato and is distinct from other known flavin-dependent monooxygenases in plants. The identification of this pathway will be important for the development of improved tomato cultivars with enhanced flavor. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, the combined effects of these two factors on ecosystem functioning have not been quantified. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is altered by global warming, with the number of species required to maintain ecosystem functioning increasing as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. This result is driven by two processes: (i) more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions, and (ii) the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect increases at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to encode different aspects of space. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record from freely behaving mice in an open field, and we found that grid cells, which are thought to encode space in terms of a grid, are organized anatomically in a distinct layer from other cell types. These data suggest that grid cells may have a distinct functional organization from other cell types. This approach could be used to study the organization of MEC neurons in other contexts. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is able to synchronize the flowering of host and parasite. This is an example of a unique means of flowering regulation in which the host is involved in the flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra are not isolated in the brain but are instead integrated into specialized systems that are likely to be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We conducted a series of experiments to understand how people feel when they’re connected to others. We found that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected they feel. This effect is driven by the speed with which people respond to their partners, rather than by the speed with which they respond to others, and it is used by third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connection between two people. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that initiates each heartbeat. SAN automaticity is regulated by a complex network of Ca2+ and voltage-gated ion channels that control the activity of SANCs. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and plays a critical role in regulating SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 is required for the maintenance of SAN Ca2+ stores and for the generation of a store-operated Ca2+ current in SANCs. These findings reveal a previously unrecognized role for STIM1 in regulating SAN Ca2+ stores and suggest that STIM1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of arrhythmias. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote rice resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We further show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. However, there is evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation may also play a role in memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability that occur in neurons when they are repeatedly activated. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenge due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures, which are able to deliver siRNA across the cell wall and into the plant cell. We show that the delivery of siRNA to the nucleus depends on the DNA nanostructure size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the nanostructure. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology and synthetic biology communities.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to eutrophication, which can alter the structure and function of coastal ecosystems. We show that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to these lakes, and that the nutrient inputs from small watersheds may be more bioavailable than those from larger tributaries. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small streams to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding is relevant to the study of complex systems that are biased toward rare configurations, such as the dynamics of financial markets, the evolution of protein networks, and the emergence of complex patterns in biological systems.

The mechanisms by which antibodies to the NMDA receptor disrupt neuronal function and cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies to the NMDA receptor can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex, which can then be sensitized to paroxysmal events. We use a dynamic model of the cortex to show that the key parameters that control the dynamics of the cortex are changed by the antibodies. We then show that these changes in the cortex can lead to paroxysmal events in a mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by antibodies to the NMDA receptor and may help to explain the diverse range of clinical symptoms observed in patients with this disease. (Show more)

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying the magnitude of such events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that this event was associated with an injection of organic matter into the ocean and anoxia of the seafloor. These results provide insights into the history of abrupt climate change and the potential impacts of such events. (Show more)

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. Despite its widespread adoption, the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation has not been quantified. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification is not reducing deforestation in the most critical areas, such as peatlands, and that certification is not a viable tool for reducing deforestation in oil palm plantations.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, of which the EXO70 subunit is the most important. The function of the exocyst complex is conserved in plants and animals, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The genetic basis of sex in vertebrates is a fundamental question in biology. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at that locus. In species with multiple sex determination loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at multiple loci. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination loci on the secondary sexual characteristics of a species, finding that the interplay of multiple sex determination loci can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-induced species that can damage photoreceptor cells. The retina is also challenged by the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoid lipofuscin) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoid lipofuscin that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that Fe levels in the retina can impact the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoid lipofuscin. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a disease characterized by the accumulation of bisretinoid lipofuscin. They also suggest that Fe levels may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of specialization in predators is often considered a dead end. We show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, is not a dead end, but rather a case of morphological diversification that has allowed these predators to diversify their prey types. Our results contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the hominin lineage leading to modern humans is relatively poor between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of the distinctive stone tools of the Middle and Later Pleistocene. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology. This suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This is an important contribution to our understanding of the evolution of the human hand. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule dual inhibitor of human serine hydroxymethyltransferse 1/2 (SHMT1/2) that blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a cancer with a high incidence of death. We propose that targeting the one-carbon unit and glycine import may be a promising strategy for treating DLBCL.

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the use of farm machinery increasing food production by a factor of 10 in the last century. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the use of fixed foraging trails by sauropods, the largest animals that walked Earth, may have been a strategy to reduce subsoil compaction. This hypothesis is supported by the fact that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth.
